name.text: Simply supported beams. Finding reaction forces. Level 2

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 150 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two reaction forces, R1 and R2, one at either end of the beam. There are two external force of 11 N and 9 N, acting at distances 66 cm and 78 cm respectively from A.

By resolving forces and taking moments about A, determine the magnitude of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

Write your answer correct to 2 d.p.

R1 = {1:NUMERICAL:= 10.48:0.01#Good job!~%0%*#Sorry. Try again.} N

R2 = {1:NUMERICAL:= 9.52:0.01#Good job!~%0%*#Sorry. Try again.} N

generalfeedback.text:
Remember that when resolving forces, the sum of the upward forces must be equal to the sum of the downward forces.

For a system in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

A simply supported beam of length 39 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two reaction forces, R1 and R2, one at either end of the beam. There are two external force of 10 N and 15 N, acting at distances 13 cm and 30 cm respectively from A.

By resolving forces and taking moments about A, determine the magnitude of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

Write your answer correct to 2 d.p.

R1 = {1:NUMERICAL:= 10.13:0.01#Good job!~%0%*#Sorry. Try again.} N

R2 = {1:NUMERICAL:= 14.87:0.01#Good job!~%0%*#Sorry. Try again.} N

generalfeedback.text:
Remember that when resolving forces, the sum of the upward forces must be equal to the sum of the downward forces.

For a system in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

generalfeedback.text:
Remember that when resolving forces, the sum of the upward forces must be equal to the sum of the downward forces.

For a system in equilibrium, the sum of the clockwise moments must be equal to the sum of the anticlockwise moments.

name.text: Simply supported beams. Finding reaction forces. Level 2

questiontext.text:
A simply supported beam of length 194 cm is shown in the figure above. There are two reaction forces, R1 and R2, one at either end of the beam. There are two external force of 11 N and 9 N, acting at distances 40 cm and 136 cm respectively from A.

By resolving forces and taking moments about A, determine the magnitude of reaction forces, R1 and R2.

Write your answer correct to 2 d.p.
